name: General Knowledge9 Online Quiz | Mixed 25 Questions | 25 Questions

questions.text: Who was the painter of 'Self Portrait With Bandaged Ear'?
questions.explanation:
Vincent van Gogh.

	Suffering from mental illness and depression he cut off part of his left ear after a quarrel with Paul Gauguin.

questions.text: According to legend which of Henry VIII's six wives had six fingers on one hand?
questions.explanation:
Anne Boleyn.

	During Anne Boleyn's beheading, Henry enjoyed a game of tennis and as soon as he heard the news of the execution went to new wife Jane Seymour's bedchamber.

questions.text: Who was the animator of the claymation heroes of 'Wallace and Gromit'?
questions.explanation:
Nick Park.

	The mild-mannered inventor (Wallace) and his canine sidekick (Gromit) have enjoyed many adventures including 'A Grand Day Out', 'A Close Shave', and 'The Wrong Trousers'.

questions.text: What did all the actors and actresses do for the following films? Bruce Willis in 'Twelve Monkeys' (1995), Sir Anthony Hopkins in 'Surviving Picasso' (1996), Demi Moore in 'G.I. Jane (1997) and Sigourney Weaver in 'Alien III' (1992).
questions.correct: Shaved their heads for their movie roles
questions.explanation: Shaved their heads for their movie roles.

questions.text: Which of the following was NOT a pizza munching Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle?
questions.explanation:
Canaletto.

	Raphael was the name of the fourth Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle.

questions.text: Which superhero had the concealed identity of Dick Grayson?
questions.explanation:
Robin.

	Bruce Wayne was Batman, Peter Parker was Spider-man and Clark Kent was Superman. Others included Babs Gordon as Batgirl, Bruce Banner as The Incredible Hulk and Diana Prince as Wonder Woman.

questions.text: Which TV character is missing from the following list? Walker, Wilson, Frazer, Godfrey, Jones, Mainwaring.
questions.explanation:
Pike.

	They are all leading characters in 'Dad's Army'. Private Walker, Sergeant Wilson, Private Frazer, Private Godfrey, Corporal Jones, Captain Mainwaring and Private Pike. This was the misadventures of the Home Guard Walmington-on-Sea platoon shown by the BBC (1968-77).

questions.text: The pop group 'Frankie Goes To Hollywood' originated from a newspaper headline about who making a film?
questions.explanation:
Frank Sinatra.

	John Frankenheimer directed 'The Birdman of Alcatraz' (1962) and 'French Connection II' (1975) 'Frankie Goes To Hollywood' hits include 'Relax', 'Two Tribes' and 'The Power of Love'.

questions.text: Which artist had a house at Giverny and a garden that provided the artist with so much inspiration - water lilies, Japanese bridge and colourful flower beds?
questions.explanation:
Claude Monet.

	Monet often painted the same scene several times such as 'Rouen Cathedral' (1892-94).

questions.text: The spaceship 'Nostromo' features in which sci fi films?
questions.explanation: Alien.

questions.text: What was the name of the three-headed dog in the film 'Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone'?
questions.explanation:
Fluffy.

	Cerberus in Greek mythology was a dog usually represented as having three heads and guarded the entrance to Hades.

questions.text: Which of the following celebrities DIDN'T die while making the movie listed by their name?
questions.correct: Marilyn Monroe in 'Some Like It Hot' (1959)
options: Roy Kinnear in 'Return of the Musketeers' (1989)
questions.explanation:
Marilyn Monroe in 'Some Like It Hot' (1959).

	Marilyn Monroe died while making the movie 'Something's Got To Give' (1962).

questions.text: Which is the odd one out of the following as it wasn't a posthumous British pop chart hit?
questions.correct: 'My Sweet Lord' by George Harrison (number 1 in 1971)
options: 'Living On My Own' by Freddie Mercury (number 1 in 1993)
questions.explanation:
'My Sweet Lord' by George Harrison (number 1 in 1971).

	Others include 'Distant Drums' by Jim Reeves (number 1 in 1966), 'Reet Petite' by Jackie Wilson (number 1 in 1986) and 'The Trail of the Lonesome Pine' by Laurel and Hardy (number 2 in 1975).

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT feature on the English version of the Monopoly board?
questions.explanation:
Fenkirk Street station.

	It should be Fenchurch Street station.

questions.text: Who was the love of 'Ivanhoe' in the Walter Scott novel?
questions.explanation: Rowena.

questions.text: Whose dog was called 'Santa's Little Helper'?
questions.explanation: Bart Simpson's.

questions.text: Which British comic has been on the wagon for fourteen years giving up alcohol, changed his name from Chris Collins and launched himself on the comedy circuit?
questions.explanation: Frank Skinner.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a John Keats poem?
questions.explanation:
'Ode to a Skylark'.

	'Ode to a Skylark' was wrote by Percy Bysshe Shelley.

questions.text: The 170 feet high 'Dodonpa' roller-coaster hits 107 mph in under two seconds. It takes one minute from start to finish to go around its 4,000 feet long track. This incredible ride is set against the backdrop of which landmark?
questions.explanation: Mount Fuji.

questions.text: Which song didn't feature in the musical 'Sweet Charity'?
questions.explanation:
'You Were Meant For Me'.

	'You Were Meant For Me' featured in the musical 'Singin' In The Rain'.

questions.text: The TV show 'Only Fools and Horses' has been sold to thirty countries including Poland, Pakistan, Australia and Hong Kong. David Jason plays the leading character Del Boy, but what is David Jason's birth surname?
questions.explanation: White.

questions.text: How many of the following celebrities first married when they were over eighteen years old? Placido Domingo, Marilyn Monroe, Tom Jones, Doris Day.
questions.explanation:
None.

	They all married at the age of sweet sixteen.

questions.text: Frank and Nancy Sinatra took the track 'Something Stupid' to number 1 in the British charts in 1967 and has subsequently been released by Robbie Williams and Nicole Kidman. Who was the songwriter?
questions.explanation: Carson Parks.

questions.text: Whose autobiography was entitled 'Golden Girl'?
questions.explanation:
Shirley Eaton.

	Her seven minutes on screen in the 1964 Bond movie 'Goldfinger' made her an international star as she was almost completely painted in gold.

questions.text: In which city would you see the famous statue of the 'Six Burghers' by Rodin outside its town hall?
questions.explanation:
Calais.

	Hope you enjoyed the quiz and learnt something new.
